docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of attention paid to the confrontations over health care. But how it's actually playing out on the ground in Montana reveals a more complicated landscape.

headline.main: The Health Care Debate in Montana

docs.snippet: There has been a lot of attention paid to the confrontations over health care. But how it's actually playing out on the ground in Montana reveals a more complicated landscape.

docs.lead_paragraph: Montana has become an unlikely center of the donnybrook over health care. Senator Max Baucus has made the state a magnet for protester and president alike.

headline.main: Baucus, and the Debate on Health Care, Go West

byline.contributor: John M. Broder contributed reporting from Coram, Mont.

headline.main: More Voices in the Health Care Debate
headline.print_headline: More Voices in the Health Care Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: If President Obama wants to jettison the now-weakened public health plan to dampen overheated opposition, he should say what he will insist on instead.
docs.snippet: If President Obama wants to jettison the now-weakened public health plan to dampen overheated opposition, he should say what he will insist on instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: On health care, why decry old-fashioned political organizing? If people believe what they’re saying, no matter who helped organize them, they’re citizens and activists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fees for doctors and medical procedures are largely a mystery to patients, particularly those seeking a doctor out of network. The health care overhaul is intended to create some clarity.

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and JEFF ZELENY

docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE Finding Democrats in the north of Idaho can be like panning for gold in the East River of New York. The area is white, rural and extremely conservative.
docs.snippet: SEATTLE      Finding Democrats in the north of Idaho can be like panning for gold in the East River of New York. The area is white, rural and extremely conservative.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama plans two major public outreach events in the next two days, hoping to galvanize support for overhauling the country's health care system. On Wednesday, he plans to hold a conference call with a coalition of liberal interfaith religious leaders. The event, at 5:30 p.m. Eastern time, will be available as a live audio stream at faithforhealth.org.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama plans two major public outreach events in hopes of galvanizing support for health care overhaul; will hold conference call with coalition of liberal interfaith religious leaders; will join 'live strategy meeting' with grass-roots supporters both online and by conference call; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama plans two major public outreach events in the next two days, hoping to galvanize support for overhauling the country's health care system.     On Wednesday, he plans to hold a conference call with a coalition of liberal interfaith...

docs.lead_paragraph: A small rebellion is brewing against AARP, the advocacy group for older Americans. From 50,000 to 60,000 AARP members have left the organization since July 1, a spokesman for the group said. Many of the defectors have destroyed their AARP cards and are switching to a relatively new group called the American Seniors Association, which bills itself as the conservative alternative to AARP.
docs.abstract: Between 50,000 and 60,000 AARP members have left organization in protest against its support for health care overhaul; AARP says it takes such rebellions seriously, but defectors represent small fraction of group's 40 million members; group lost 70,000 to 80,000 members over its support of Medicare drug benefit (S)
docs.snippet: A small rebellion is brewing against AARP, the advocacy group for older Americans.      From 50,000 to  60,000 AARP members have left the organization since July 1, a spokesman for the group said. Many of the defectors have destroyed their AARP cards...
